  7. Read off the hex code (it starts with a hashtag symbol (#))

Then insert the HEX codes into our tool, and compare the outputted ratio to the WCAG guidelines.

Our colour palettes have been designed to meet best practice guidelines for accessibility, including the WCAG. We encourage you to use these in your data visualisations, but be mindful of any branding your institution may have.

Accessibility & Formatting General Principles

Using colour

Effective use of colour in data visualisation helps the brain quickly identify differences and can aid interpretation. However, using the wrong colours, too many colours, or unnecessary colours, can have the opposite effect.

Think carefully before you introduce additional colours into a chart. Ask yourself:

  • Do you really need the colours?
  • Do they make your key message or messages clearer?
  • The colours you use should be sufficiently unique in tone and contrast. They should also account for users with low vision and colour blindness.

The guidance below expands on how you can achieve this. Colour guidance on axes, chart labels, annotations, and gridlines is included in the Other Formatting Considerations section below.

Colour should be used to enhance your data visualisation. You should use different colours when they help to highlight differences in the data, but they should ideally not be the only way you convey those differences.

The WCAG state that: 1.4.1. Use of colour

Colour is not used as the only visual means of conveying information. This means that you should help users understand charts without relying only on colour. To do this, you should avoid using legends in line charts and pie charts. Instead, label the categories and lines in your chart.

If you need to use a legend for stacked or clustered bar charts, order the legend to match the categories as they appear in the chart. This does not completely solve the problem, but it can help users work out the series labels without relying only on colour.

Use the right number of colours

Some data visualisations, such as a simple bar chart with one independent and one dependent variable, only need one colour across categories. The user is much more likely to compare the bars when they look alike than when they look different. Sometimes it is helpful to highlight a specific category to bring it into focus. In these cases, use one colour for this category (for example, dark blue), while keeping the others the same (for example, grey).

Other types of data visualisation, such as a clustered bar chart, or a line graph showing multiple time series, are likely to benefit from having multiple colours. However, you should avoid using more than five colours in the same chart. Having more than five colours makes it harder for users to distinguish between categories.

When people look at a chart with lots of colours, they try to work out what those different colours mean. If your colours suggest meanings that are not there the user will waste time and effort trying to understand them. This creates cognitive burden on the user and makes it harder for them to engage with your analysis.

can make its content difficult to see. Data visualisations that use an image as a background are also likely to fail accessibility criteria from WCAG.

Consider associations

Colours come with their own symbolic associations. Think about these when choosing your palette. Consider whether your colours are appropriate. If done well, you can exploit these associations to help your users understand your visualisation more quickly.

For example, people tend to link blue with water and green with grass. Using these types of links in data visualisations can help people understand information faster. If you use colours that go against these associations, it might take users longer to understand your chart. For example, it

would take users longer to understand you were talking about grass if you used the colour red to represent it. Colours can also have cultural associations that we react to consciously or unconsciously. These associations vary across countries and groups. Make sure you investigate any possible associations first if you are sharing your data visualisations with international audiences.

f shades of a similar colour are used across categories in a chart, users may assume they are related. If your data has distinct (i.e. discrete or unrelated) categories, then you should use distinct colours.

Keep your colour palettes consistent

If you have multiple data visualisations in a publication, assign the same colour to the same categories in each one. If you change the way you use colours in a series of charts it becomes harder for users to follow the story. It can also cause them to mistake one data series for another, especially if a user is skim reading.

Consider contrast ratios

Although differences in tone (for example, red, green, and blue) can make your colours distinguishable for many users, this may not be enough for users with colour-blindness. One of the best ways we can account for users with colour-blindness is via the use of contrast, which is typically measured via contrast ratios.

Effective use of contrast also ensures that your visualisations are readable if, for example, it is printed in black and white. It may be helpful to switch your display settings to greyscale to test whether you can identify differences, whether you have colour-blindness or not.

Contrast ratios range between 1:1 (white on white) and 21:1 (black on white). Generally, a moderate level of contrast is the most desirable, but the WCAG include specific thresholds you should aim to pass at minimum.

There are two success criteria in the WCAG that refer to contrast ratios: 1.4.11.

The visual presentation of parts of graphics required to understand the content have a contrast ratio of at least 3 to 1 against adjacent colours except when a particular presentation is essential. This means that all chart elements (such as categories in a bar chart) must have at least a 3:1 contrast ratio with adjacent colours, unless the presentation is essential for communicating your key message. 1.4.3. Contrast (minimum)

The visual presentation of text and images of text has a contrast ratio of at least 4.5:1, except for large scale text which needs to have a contrast ratio of at least 3:1. This means you should make sure that all chart labels and annotations have at least a 4.5: contrast ratio with the background colour.

Large scale text; is defined as at least 18 point regular or 14 point bold. However, when charts are presented as images, the text size often changes. It is therefore always best to aim for a 4.5:1 contrast ratio. To go even further, WCAG success criterion 1.4.6 states that text and images of text should have a contrast ratio of at least 7:1. As a level AAA criterion, this would meet and then exceed legal requirements in the UK.

Never use an image as a background to your data visualisation. This can make its content difficult to see. Data visualisations that use an image as a background are also likely to fail accessibility criteria from WCAG.

Calculate a contrast ratio

To calculate the contrast ratio between two colours to check if they meet these requirements, use our tool below. You will need to find the HEX codes of your colours first. To do so in Microsoft programmes:

  1. Select the graphical element or object of interest
  2. Select the ‘Format’ ribbon
  3. Select the ‘Shape Fill’ dropdown
  4. Select ‘More Fill Colours’
  5. Select ‘Custom’
  6. If your background colour is white, the hex code for white is: #FFFFFF.
  7. Read off the hex code (it starts with a hashtag symbol (#))

Then insert the HEX codes into our tool, and compare the outputted ratio to the WCAG guidelines.

Our colour palettes have been designed to meet best practice guidelines for accessibility, including the WCAG. We encourage you to use these in your data visualisations, but be mindful of any branding your institution may have.

Accessibility & Formatting General Principles

Using colour

Effective use of colour in data visualisation helps the brain quickly identify differences and can aid interpretation. However, using the wrong colours, too many colours, or unnecessary colours, can have the opposite effect.

Think carefully before you introduce additional colours into a chart. Ask yourself:

  • Do you really need the colours?
  • Do they make your key message or messages clearer?
  • The colours you use should be sufficiently unique in tone and contrast. They should also account for users with low vision and colour blindness.

The guidance below expands on how you can achieve this. Colour guidance on axes, chart labels, annotations, and gridlines is included in the Other Formatting Considerations section below.

Colour should be used to enhance your data visualisation. You should use different colours when they help to highlight differences in the data, but they should ideally not be the only way you convey those differences.

The WCAG state that: 1.4.1. Use of colour

Colour is not used as the only visual means of conveying information. This means that you should help users understand charts without relying only on colour. To do this, you should avoid using legends in line charts and pie charts. Instead, label the categories and lines in your chart.

If you need to use a legend for stacked or clustered bar charts, order the legend to match the categories as they appear in the chart. This does not completely solve the problem, but it can help users work out the series labels without relying only on colour.

Use the right number of colours

Some data visualisations, such as a simple bar chart with one independent and one dependent variable, only need one colour across categories. The user is much more likely to compare the bars when they look alike than when they look different. Sometimes it is helpful to highlight a specific category to bring it into focus. In these cases, use one colour for this category (for example, dark blue), while keeping the others the same (for example, grey).

Other types of data visualisation, such as a clustered bar chart, or a line graph showing multiple time series, are likely to benefit from having multiple colours. However, you should avoid using more than five colours in the same chart. Having more than five colours makes it harder for users to distinguish between categories.

When people look at a chart with lots of colours, they try to work out what those different colours mean. This creates cognitive burden on the user and makes it harder for them to engage with your analysis.

can make its content difficult to see. Data visualisations that use an image as a background are also likely to fail accessibility criteria from WCAG.

Consider associations

Colours come with their own symbolic associations. Think about these when choosing your palette. Consider whether your colours are appropriate. If done well, you can exploit these associations to help your users understand your visualisation more quickly.

For example, people tend to link blue with water and green with grass. Using these types of links in data visualisations can help people understand information faster. If you use colours that go against these associations, it might take users longer to understand your chart. For example, it

would take users longer to understand you were talking about grass if you used the colour red to represent it. Colours can also have cultural associations that we react to consciously or unconsciously. These associations vary across countries and groups. Make sure you investigate any possible associations first if you are sharing your data visualisations with international audiences.

f shades of a similar colour are used across categories in a chart, users may assume they are related. If your data has distinct (i.e. discrete or unrelated) categories, then you should use distinct colours.

Keep your colour palettes consistent

If you have multiple data visualisations in a publication, assign the same colour to the same categories in each one. If you change the way you use colours in a series of charts it becomes harder for users to follow the story. It can also cause them to mistake one data series for another, especially if a user is skim reading.

Although differences in tone (for example, red, green, and blue) can make your colours distinguishable for many users, this may not be enough for users with colour-blindness. One of the best ways we can account for users with colour-blindness is via the use of contrast, which is typically measured via contrast ratios.

Contrast (minimum)

This means you should make sure that all chart labels and annotations have at least a 4.5: contrast ratio with the background colour.

Large scale text; is defined as at least 18 point regular or 14 point bold. However, when charts are presented as images, the text size often changes. It is therefore always best to aim for a 4.5:1 contrast ratio. To go even further, WCAG success criterion 1.4.6 states that text and images of text should have a contrast ratio of at least 7:1. As a level AAA criterion, this would meet and then exceed legal requirements in the UK.

Never use an image as a background to your data visualisation. This can make its content difficult to see. Data visualisations that use an image as a background are also likely to fail accessibility criteria from WCAG.

Calculate a contrast ratio

To calculate the contrast ratio between two colours to check if they meet these requirements, use our tool below. You will need to find the HEX codes of your colours first. To do so in Microsoft programmes:

  1. Select the graphical element or object of interest
  2. Select the ‘Format’ ribbon
  3. Select the ‘Shape Fill’ dropdown
  4. Select ‘More Fill Colours’
  5. Select ‘Custom’
  6. If your background colour is white, the hex code for white is: #FFFFFF.
  7. Read off the hex code (it starts with a hashtag symbol (#))

Then insert the HEX codes into our tool, and compare the outputted ratio to the WCAG guidelines.

Our colour palettes have been designed to meet best practice guidelines for accessibility, including the WCAG. We encourage you to use these in your data visualisations, but be mindful of any branding your institution may have.

would take users longer to understand you were talking about grass if you used the colour red to represent it. Calculate a contrast ratio

To calculate the contrast ratio between two colours to check if they meet these requirements, use our tool below. You will need to find the HEX codes of your colours first. To do so in Microsoft programmes:

  1. Select the graphical element or object of interest
  2. Select the ‘Format’ ribbon
  3. Select the ‘Shape Fill’ dropdown
  4. Select ‘More Fill Colours’
  5. Select ‘Custom’
  6. If your background colour is white, the hex code for white is: #FFFFFF.
  7. Read off the hex code (it starts with a hashtag symbol (#))

Then insert the HEX codes into our tool, and compare the outputted ratio to the WCAG guidelines.

Our colour palettes have been designed to meet best practice guidelines for accessibility, including the WCAG. We encourage you to use these in your data visualisations, but be mindful of any branding your institution may have.

Accessibility & Formatting General Principles

Using colour

Effective use of colour in data visualisation helps the brain quickly identify differences and can aid interpretation. However, using the wrong colours, too many colours, or unnecessary colours, can have the opposite effect.

Think carefully before you introduce additional colours into a chart. Ask yourself:

  • Do you really need the colours?
  • Do they make your key message or messages clearer?
  • The colours you use should be sufficiently unique in tone and contrast. They should also account for users with low vision and colour blindness.

The guidance below expands on how you can achieve this. Colour guidance on axes, chart labels, annotations, and gridlines is included in the Other Formatting Considerations section below.

Colour should be used to enhance your data visualisation. You should use different colours when they help to highlight differences in the data, but they should ideally not be the only way you convey those differences.

The WCAG state that: 1.4.1. Use of colour

Colour is not used as the only visual means of conveying information. This means that you should help users understand charts without relying only on colour. To do this, you should avoid using legends in line charts and pie charts. Instead, label the categories and lines in your chart.

If you need to use a legend for stacked or clustered bar charts, order the legend to match the categories as they appear in the chart. This does not completely solve the problem, but it can help users work out the series labels without relying only on colour.

Use the right number of colours

Some data visualisations, such as a simple bar chart with one independent and one dependent variable, only need one colour across categories. The user is much more likely to compare the bars when they look alike than when they look different. Sometimes it is helpful to highlight a specific category to bring it into focus. In these cases, use one colour for this category (for example, dark blue), while keeping the others the same (for example, grey).

Other types of data visualisation, such as a clustered bar chart, or a line graph showing multiple time series, are likely to benefit from having multiple colours. However, you should avoid using more than five colours in the same chart. Having more than five colours makes it harder for users to distinguish between categories.

When people look at a chart with lots of colours, they try to work out what those different colours mean. If your colours suggest meanings that are not there the user will waste time and effort trying to understand them. This creates cognitive burden on the user and makes it harder for them to engage with your analysis.

can make its content difficult to see. Data visualisations that use an image as a background are also likely to fail accessibility criteria from WCAG.

Consider associations

Colours come with their own symbolic associations. Think about these when choosing your palette. Consider whether your colours are appropriate. If done well, you can exploit these associations to help your users understand your visualisation more quickly.

For example, people tend to link blue with water and green with grass. Using these types of links in data visualisations can help people understand information faster. If you use colours that go against these associations, it might take users longer to understand your chart. For example, it

would take users longer to understand you were talking about grass if you used the colour red to represent it. Colours can also have cultural associations that we react to consciously or unconsciously. These associations vary across countries and groups. Make sure you investigate any possible associations first if you are sharing your data visualisations with international audiences.

f shades of a similar colour are used across categories in a chart, users may assume they are related. If your data has distinct (i.e. discrete or unrelated) categories, then you should use distinct colours.

Keep your colour palettes consistent

If you have multiple data visualisations in a publication, assign the same colour to the same categories in each one. If you change the way you use colours in a series of charts it becomes harder for users to follow the story. It can also cause them to mistake one data series for another, especially if a user is skim reading.

Consider contrast ratios

Although differences in tone (for example, red, green, and blue) can make your colours distinguishable for many users, this may not be enough for users with colour-blindness. One of the best ways we can account for users with colour-blindness is via the use of contrast, which is typically measured via contrast ratios.

Effective use of contrast also ensures that your visualisations are readable if, for example, it is printed in black and white. It may be helpful to switch your display settings to greyscale to test whether you can identify differences, whether you have colour-blindness or not.

Contrast ratios range between 1:1 (white on white) and 21:1 (black on white). Generally, a moderate level of contrast is the most desirable, but the WCAG include specific thresholds you should aim to pass at minimum.

There are two success criteria in the WCAG that refer to contrast ratios: 1.4.11.

The visual presentation of parts of graphics required to understand the content have a contrast ratio of at least 3 to 1 against adjacent colours except when a particular presentation is essential. This means that all chart elements (such as categories in a bar chart) must have at least a 3:1 contrast ratio with adjacent colours, unless the presentation is essential for communicating your key message. 1.4.3. Contrast (minimum)

The visual presentation of text and images of text has a contrast ratio of at least 4.5:1, except for large scale text which needs to have a contrast ratio of at least 3:1. This means you should make sure that all chart labels and annotations have at least a 4.5: contrast ratio with the background colour.

Large scale text; is defined as at least 18 point regular or 14 point bold. However, when charts are presented as images, the text size often changes. It is therefore always best to aim for a 4.5:1 contrast ratio. To go even further, WCAG success criterion 1.4.6 states that text and images of text should have a contrast ratio of at least 7:1. As a level AAA criterion, this would meet and then exceed legal requirements in the UK.

Never use an image as a background to your data visualisation. This can make its content difficult to see. Data visualisations that use an image as a background are also likely to fail accessibility criteria from WCAG.

Calculate a contrast ratio

To calculate the contrast ratio between two colours to check if they meet these requirements, use our tool below. You will need to find the HEX codes of your colours first. To do so in Microsoft programmes:

  1. Select the graphical element or object of interest
  2. Select the ‘Format’ ribbon
  3. Select the ‘Shape Fill’ dropdown
  4. Select ‘More Fill Colours’
  5. Select ‘Custom’
  6. If your background colour is white, the hex code for white is: #FFFFFF.
  7. Read off the hex code (it starts with a hashtag symbol (#))

Then insert the HEX codes into our tool, and compare the outputted ratio to the WCAG guidelines.

Our colour palettes have been designed to meet best practice guidelines for accessibility, including the WCAG. We encourage you to use these in your data visualisations, but be mindful of any branding your institution may have.

Using colour

Effective use of colour in data visualisation helps the brain quickly identify differences and can aid interpretation. However, using the wrong colours, too many colours, or unnecessary colours, can have the opposite effect.

The guidance below expands on how you can achieve this. Colour guidance on axes, chart labels, annotations, and gridlines is included in the Other Formatting Considerations section below.

The WCAG state that: 1.4.1. Use of colour

Colour is not used as the only visual means of conveying information. This means that you should help users understand charts without relying only on colour. To do this, you should avoid using legends in line charts and pie charts. Instead, label the categories and lines in your chart.

If you need to use a legend for stacked or clustered bar charts, order the legend to match the categories as they appear in the chart. This does not completely solve the problem, but it can help users work out the series labels without relying only on colour.

Use the right number of colours

Some data visualisations, such as a simple bar chart with one independent and one dependent variable, only need one colour across categories. In these cases, use one colour for this category (for example, dark blue), while keeping the others the same (for example, grey).

Other types of data visualisation, such as a clustered bar chart, or a line graph showing multiple time series, are likely to benefit from having multiple colours. However, you should avoid using more than five colours in the same chart. Having more than five colours makes it harder for users to distinguish between categories.

This creates cognitive burden on the user and makes it harder for them to engage with your analysis.

can make its content difficult to see. Data visualisations that use an image as a background are also likely to fail accessibility criteria from WCAG.

Consider associations

Colours come with their own symbolic associations. Think about these when choosing your palette. Consider whether your colours are appropriate. If done well, you can exploit these associations to help your users understand your visualisation more quickly.

For example, people tend to link blue with water and green with grass. Using these types of links in data visualisations can help people understand information faster. If you use colours that go against these associations, it might take users longer to understand your chart. For example, it

would take users longer to understand you were talking about grass if you used the colour red to represent it. Colours can also have cultural associations that we react to consciously or unconsciously. These associations vary across countries and groups. Make sure you investigate any possible associations first if you are sharing your data visualisations with international audiences.

f shades of a similar colour are used across categories in a chart, users may assume they are related. If your data has distinct (i.e. discrete or unrelated) categories, then you should use distinct colours.

Keep your colour palettes consistent

If you have multiple data visualisations in a publication, assign the same colour to the same categories in each one. If you change the way you use colours in a series of charts it becomes harder for users to follow the story. It can also cause them to mistake one data series for another, especially if a user is skim reading.

Contrast (minimum)

This means you should make sure that all chart labels and annotations have at least a 4.5: contrast ratio with the background colour.

Large scale text; is defined as at least 18 point regular or 14 point bold. However, when charts are presented as images, the text size often changes. It is therefore always best to aim for a 4.5:1 contrast ratio. To go even further, WCAG success criterion 1.4.6 states that text and images of text should have a contrast ratio of at least 7:1. As a level AAA criterion, this would meet and then exceed legal requirements in the UK.

Never use an image as a background to your data visualisation. This can make its content difficult to see. Data visualisations that use an image as a background are also likely to fail accessibility criteria from WCAG.

  1. Select the graphical element or object of interest
  2. Select the ‘Format’ ribbon
  3. Select the ‘Shape Fill’ dropdown
  4. Select ‘More Fill Colours’
  5. Select ‘Custom’
  6. If your background colour is white, the hex code for white is: #FFFFFF.
  7. Read off the hex code (it starts with a hashtag symbol (#))

Then insert the HEX codes into our tool, and compare the outputted ratio to the WCAG guidelines.

Our colour palettes have been designed to meet best practice guidelines for accessibility, including the WCAG. We encourage you to use these in your data visualisations, but be mindful of any branding your institution may have.

Consider associations

Colours come with their own symbolic associations. Think about these when choosing your palette. Consider whether your colours are appropriate. If done well, you can exploit these associations to help your users understand your visualisation more quickly.

For example, people tend to link blue with water and green with grass. Using these types of links in data visualisations can help people understand information faster. If you use colours that go against these associations, it might take users longer to understand your chart. For example, it

would take users longer to understand you were talking about grass if you used the colour red to represent it. Colours can also have cultural associations that we react to consciously or unconsciously. These associations vary across countries and groups. Make sure you investigate any possible associations first if you are sharing your data visualisations with international audiences.

f shades of a similar colour are used across categories in a chart, users may assume they are related. If your data has distinct (i.e. discrete or unrelated) categories, then you should use distinct colours.

This means you should make sure that all chart labels and annotations have at least a 4.5: contrast ratio with the background colour.

Large scale text; is defined as at least 18 point regular or 14 point bold. However, when charts are presented as images, the text size often changes. It is therefore always best to aim for a 4.5:1 contrast ratio. To go even further, WCAG success criterion 1.4.6 states that text and images of text should have a contrast ratio of at least 7:1. As a level AAA criterion, this would meet and then exceed legal requirements in the UK.

Never use an image as a background to your data visualisation. This can make its content difficult to see. Data visualisations that use an image as a background are also likely to fail accessibility criteria from WCAG.

Calculate a contrast ratio

To calculate the contrast ratio between two colours to check if they meet these requirements, use our tool below. You will need to find the HEX codes of your colours first. To do so in Microsoft programmes:

  1. Select the graphical element or object of interest
  2. Select the ‘Format’ ribbon
  3. Select the ‘Shape Fill’ dropdown
  4. Select ‘More Fill Colours’
  5. Select ‘Custom’
  6. If your background colour is white, the hex code for white is: #FFFFFF.
  7. Read off the hex code (it starts with a hashtag symbol (#))

Then insert the HEX codes into our tool, and compare the outputted ratio to the WCAG guidelines.

Our colour palettes have been designed to meet best practice guidelines for accessibility, including the WCAG. We encourage you to use these in your data visualisations, but be mindful of any branding your institution may have.

Accessibility & Formatting General Principles

Using colour

Effective use of colour in data visualisation helps the brain quickly identify differences and can aid interpretation. However, using the wrong colours, too many colours, or unnecessary colours, can have the opposite effect.

Think carefully before you introduce additional colours into a chart. Ask yourself:

  • Do you really need the colours?
  • Do they make your key message or messages clearer?
  • The colours you use should be sufficiently unique in tone and contrast. They should also account for users with low vision and colour blindness.

The guidance below expands on how you can achieve this. Colour guidance on axes, chart labels, annotations, and gridlines is included in the Other Formatting Considerations section below.

Colour should be used to enhance your data visualisation. You should use different colours when they help to highlight differences in the data, but they should ideally not be the only way you convey those differences.

The WCAG state that: 1.4.1. Use of colour

Colour is not used as the only visual means of conveying information. This means that you should help users understand charts without relying only on colour. To do this, you should avoid using legends in line charts and pie charts. Instead, label the categories and lines in your chart.

If you need to use a legend for stacked or clustered bar charts, order the legend to match the categories as they appear in the chart. This does not completely solve the problem, but it can help users work out the series labels without relying only on colour.

Use the right number of colours

Some data visualisations, such as a simple bar chart with one independent and one dependent variable, only need one colour across categories. The user is much more likely to compare the bars when they look alike than when they look different. Sometimes it is helpful to highlight a specific category to bring it into focus. In these cases, use one colour for this category (for example, dark blue), while keeping the others the same (for example, grey).

Other types of data visualisation, such as a clustered bar chart, or a line graph showing multiple time series, are likely to benefit from having multiple colours. However, you should avoid using more than five colours in the same chart. Having more than five colours makes it harder for users to distinguish between categories.

When people look at a chart with lots of colours, they try to work out what those different colours mean. If your colours suggest meanings that are not there the user will waste time and effort trying to understand them. This creates cognitive burden on the user and makes it harder for them to engage with your analysis.

can make its content difficult to see. Data visualisations that use an image as a background are also likely to fail accessibility criteria from WCAG.

Consider associations

Colours come with their own symbolic associations. Think about these when choosing your palette. Consider whether your colours are appropriate. If done well, you can exploit these associations to help your users understand your visualisation more quickly.

For example, people tend to link blue with water and green with grass. Using these types of links in data visualisations can help people understand information faster. If you use colours that go against these associations, it might take users longer to understand your chart. For example, it

would take users longer to understand you were talking about grass if you used the colour red to represent it. Colours can also have cultural associations that we react to consciously or unconsciously. These associations vary across countries and groups. Make sure you investigate any possible associations first if you are sharing your data visualisations with international audiences.

f shades of a similar colour are used across categories in a chart, users may assume they are related. If your data has distinct (i.e. discrete or unrelated) categories, then you should use distinct colours.

Keep your colour palettes consistent

If you have multiple data visualisations in a publication, assign the same colour to the same categories in each one. If you change the way you use colours in a series of charts it becomes harder for users to follow the story. It can also cause them to mistake one data series for another, especially if a user is skim reading.

Consider contrast ratios

Although differences in tone (for example, red, green, and blue) can make your colours distinguishable for many users, this may not be enough for users with colour-blindness. One of the best ways we can account for users with colour-blindness is via the use of contrast, which is typically measured via contrast ratios.

Effective use of contrast also ensures that your visualisations are readable if, for example, it is printed in black and white. It may be helpful to switch your display settings to greyscale to test whether you can identify differences, whether you have colour-blindness or not.

Contrast ratios range between 1:1 (white on white) and 21:1 (black on white). Generally, a moderate level of contrast is the most desirable, but the WCAG include specific thresholds you should aim to pass at minimum.

There are two success criteria in the WCAG that refer to contrast ratios: 1.4.11.

The visual presentation of parts of graphics required to understand the content have a contrast ratio of at least 3 to 1 against adjacent colours except when a particular presentation is essential. This means that all chart elements (such as categories in a bar chart) must have at least a 3:1 contrast ratio with adjacent colours, unless the presentation is essential for communicating your key message. 1.4.3. Contrast (minimum)

The visual presentation of text and images of text has a contrast ratio of at least 4.5:1, except for large scale text which needs to have a contrast ratio of at least 3:1. This means you should make sure that all chart labels and annotations have at least a 4.5: contrast ratio with the background colour.

Large scale text; is defined as at least 18 point regular or 14 point bold. However, when charts are presented as images, the text size often changes. It is therefore always best to aim for a 4.5:1 contrast ratio. To go even further, WCAG success criterion 1.4.6 states that text and images of text should have a contrast ratio of at least 7:1. As a level AAA criterion, this would meet and then exceed legal requirements in the UK.

Never use an image as a background to your data visualisation. This can make its content difficult to see. Data visualisations that use an image as a background are also likely to fail accessibility criteria from WCAG.

Calculate a contrast ratio

To calculate the contrast ratio between two colours to check if they meet these requirements, use our tool below. You will need to find the HEX codes of your colours first. To do so in Microsoft programmes:

  1. Select the graphical element or object of interest
  2. Select the ‘Format’ ribbon
  3. Select the ‘Shape Fill’ dropdown
  4. Select ‘More Fill Colours’
  5. Select ‘Custom’
  6. If your background colour is white, the hex code for white is: #FFFFFF.
  7. Read off the hex code (it starts with a hashtag symbol (#))

Then insert the HEX codes into our tool, and compare the outputted ratio to the WCAG guidelines.

Our colour palettes have been designed to meet best practice guidelines for accessibility, including the WCAG. We encourage you to use these in your data visualisations, but be mindful of any branding your institution may have.

Accessibility & Formatting General Principles

Using colour

Effective use of colour in data visualisation helps the brain quickly identify differences and can aid interpretation. However, using the wrong colours, too many colours, or unnecessary colours, can have the opposite effect.

Think carefully before you introduce additional colours into a chart. Ask yourself:

  • Do you really need the colours?
  • Do they make your key message or messages clearer?
  • The colours you use should be sufficiently unique in tone and contrast. They should also account for users with low vision and colour blindness.

The guidance below expands on how you can achieve this. Colour guidance on axes, chart labels, annotations, and gridlines is included in the Other Formatting Considerations section below.

Colour should be used to enhance your data visualisation. You should use different colours when they help to highlight differences in the data, but they should ideally not be the only way you convey those differences.

The WCAG state that: 1.4.1. Use of colour

Colour is not used as the only visual means of conveying information. This means that you should help users understand charts without relying only on colour. To do this, you should avoid using legends in line charts and pie charts. Instead, label the categories and lines in your chart.

If you need to use a legend for stacked or clustered bar charts, order the legend to match the categories as they appear in the chart. This does not completely solve the problem, but it can help users work out the series labels without relying only on colour.

Use the right number of colours

In these cases, use one colour for this category (for example, dark blue), while keeping the others the same (for example, grey).

Other types of data visualisation, such as a clustered bar chart, or a line graph showing multiple time series, are likely to benefit from having multiple colours. can make its content difficult to see. Data visualisations that use an image as a background are also likely to fail accessibility criteria from WCAG.

Consider associations

Colours come with their own symbolic associations. Think about these when choosing your palette. Consider whether your colours are appropriate. If done well, you can exploit these associations to help your users understand your visualisation more quickly.

For example, people tend to link blue with water and green with grass. Using these types of links in data visualisations can help people understand information faster. If you use colours that go against these associations, it might take users longer to understand your chart. For example, it

would take users longer to understand you were talking about grass if you used the colour red to represent it. Colours can also have cultural associations that we react to consciously or unconsciously. These associations vary across countries and groups. Make sure you investigate any possible associations first if you are sharing your data visualisations with international audiences.

f shades of a similar colour are used across categories in a chart, users may assume they are related. If your data has distinct (i.e. discrete or unrelated) categories, then you should use distinct colours.

Keep your colour palettes consistent

If you have multiple data visualisations in a publication, assign the same colour to the same categories in each one. If you change the way you use colours in a series of charts it becomes harder for users to follow the story. It can also cause them to mistake one data series for another, especially if a user is skim reading.

This means you should make sure that all chart labels and annotations have at least a 4.5: contrast ratio with the background colour.

Large scale text; is defined as at least 18 point regular or 14 point bold. However, when charts are presented as images, the text size often changes. It is therefore always best to aim for a 4.5:1 contrast ratio. To go even further, WCAG success criterion 1.4.6 states that text and images of text should have a contrast ratio of at least 7:1. As a level AAA criterion, this would meet and then exceed legal requirements in the UK.

To calculate the contrast ratio between two colours to check if they meet these requirements, use our tool below. You will need to find the HEX codes of your colours first. To do so in Microsoft programmes:

  1. Select the graphical element or object of interest
  2. Select the ‘Format’ ribbon
  3. Select the ‘Shape Fill’ dropdown
  4. Select ‘More Fill Colours’
  5. Select ‘Custom’
  6. If your background colour is white, the hex code for white is: #FFFFFF.
  7. Read off the hex code (it starts with a hashtag symbol (#))

Then insert the HEX codes into our tool, and compare the outputted ratio to the WCAG guidelines.

Our colour palettes have been designed to meet best practice guidelines for accessibility, including the WCAG. We encourage you to use these in your data visualisations, but be mindful of any branding your institution may have.

There are two success criteria in the WCAG that refer to contrast ratios: 1.4.11.

The visual presentation of parts of graphics required to understand the content have a contrast ratio of at least 3 to 1 against adjacent colours except when a particular presentation is essential. This means that all chart elements (such as categories in a bar chart) must have at least a 3:1 contrast ratio with adjacent colours, unless the presentation is essential for communicating your key message. 1.4.3. Contrast (minimum)

The visual presentation of text and images of text has a contrast ratio of at least 4.5:1, except for large scale text which needs to have a contrast ratio of at least 3:1. This means you should make sure that all chart labels and annotations have at least a 4.5: contrast ratio with the background colour.

Large scale text; is defined as at least 18 point regular or 14 point bold. However, when charts are presented as images, the text size often changes. It is therefore always best to aim for a 4.5:1 contrast ratio. To go even further, WCAG success criterion 1.4.6 states that text and images of text should have a contrast ratio of at least 7:1. As a level AAA criterion, this would meet and then exceed legal requirements in the UK.

Never use an image as a background to your data visualisation. This can make its content difficult to see. Data visualisations that use an image as a background are also likely to fail accessibility criteria from WCAG.

Calculate a contrast ratio

To calculate the contrast ratio between two colours to check if they meet these requirements, use our tool below. You will need to find the HEX codes of your colours first. To do so in Microsoft programmes:

  1. Select the graphical element or object of interest
  2. Select the ‘Format’ ribbon
  3. Select the ‘Shape Fill’ dropdown
  4. Select ‘More Fill Colours’
  5. Select ‘Custom’
  6. If your background colour is white, the hex code for white is: #FFFFFF.
  7. Read off the hex code (it starts with a hashtag symbol (#))

Then insert the HEX codes into our tool, and compare the outputted ratio to the WCAG guidelines.

Our colour palettes have been designed to meet best practice guidelines for accessibility, including the WCAG. We encourage you to use these in your data visualisations, but be mindful of any branding your institution may have.

Accessibility & Formatting General Principles

Using colour

Effective use of colour in data visualisation helps the brain quickly identify differences and can aid interpretation. However, using the wrong colours, too many colours, or unnecessary colours, can have the opposite effect.

Think carefully before you introduce additional colours into a chart. Ask yourself:

  • Do you really need the colours?
  • Do they make your key message or messages clearer?
  • The colours you use should be sufficiently unique in tone and contrast. They should also account for users with low vision and colour blindness.

The guidance below expands on how you can achieve this. Colour guidance on axes, chart labels, annotations, and gridlines is included in the Other Formatting Considerations section below.

Colour should be used to enhance your data visualisation. You should use different colours when they help to highlight differences in the data, but they should ideally not be the only way you convey those differences.

The WCAG state that: 1.4.1. Use of colour

Colour is not used as the only visual means of conveying information. This means that you should help users understand charts without relying only on colour. To do this, you should avoid using legends in line charts and pie charts. Instead, label the categories and lines in your chart.

If you need to use a legend for stacked or clustered bar charts, order the legend to match the categories as they appear in the chart. This does not completely solve the problem, but it can help users work out the series labels without relying only on colour.

Use the right number of colours

Some data visualisations, such as a simple bar chart with one independent and one dependent variable, only need one colour across categories. The user is much more likely to compare the bars when they look alike than when they look different. Sometimes it is helpful to highlight a specific category to bring it into focus. In these cases, use one colour for this category (for example, dark blue), while keeping the others the same (for example, grey).

Other types of data visualisation, such as a clustered bar chart, or a line graph showing multiple time series, are likely to benefit from having multiple colours. However, you should avoid using more than five colours in the same chart. Having more than five colours makes it harder for users to distinguish between categories.

When people look at a chart with lots of colours, they try to work out what those different colours mean. If your colours suggest meanings that are not there the user will waste time and effort trying to understand them. This creates cognitive burden on the user and makes it harder for them to engage with your analysis.

can make its content difficult to see. Data visualisations that use an image as a background are also likely to fail accessibility criteria from WCAG.

Consider associations

Colours come with their own symbolic associations. Think about these when choosing your palette. Consider whether your colours are appropriate. If done well, you can exploit these associations to help your users understand your visualisation more quickly.

For example, people tend to link blue with water and green with grass. Using these types of links in data visualisations can help people understand information faster. If you use colours that go against these associations, it might take users longer to understand your chart. For example, it

would take users longer to understand you were talking about grass if you used the colour red to represent it. Colours can also have cultural associations that we react to consciously or unconsciously. These associations vary across countries and groups. Make sure you investigate any possible associations first if you are sharing your data visualisations with international audiences.

f shades of a similar colour are used across categories in a chart, users may assume they are related. If your data has distinct (i.e. discrete or unrelated) categories, then you should use distinct colours.

Keep your colour palettes consistent

If you have multiple data visualisations in a publication, assign the same colour to the same categories in each one. If you change the way you use colours in a series of charts it becomes harder for users to follow the story. It can also cause them to mistake one data series for another, especially if a user is skim reading.

Consider contrast ratios

Although differences in tone (for example, red, green, and blue) can make your colours distinguishable for many users, this may not be enough for users with colour-blindness. One of the best ways we can account for users with colour-blindness is via the use of contrast, which is typically measured via contrast ratios.

Effective use of contrast also ensures that your visualisations are readable if, for example, it is printed in black and white. It may be helpful to switch your display settings to greyscale to test whether you can identify differences, whether you have colour-blindness or not.

Contrast ratios range between 1:1 (white on white) and 21:1 (black on white). Generally, a moderate level of contrast is the most desirable, but the WCAG include specific thresholds you should aim to pass at minimum.

There are two success criteria in the WCAG that refer to contrast ratios: 1.4.11.

The visual presentation of parts of graphics required to understand the content have a contrast ratio of at least 3 to 1 against adjacent colours except when a particular presentation is essential. This means that all chart elements (such as categories in a bar chart) must have at least a 3:1 contrast ratio with adjacent colours, unless the presentation is essential for communicating your key message. 1.4.3. Contrast (minimum)

The visual presentation of text and images of text has a contrast ratio of at least 4.5:1, except for large scale text which needs to have a contrast ratio of at least 3:1. This means you should make sure that all chart labels and annotations have at least a 4.5: contrast ratio with the background colour.

Large scale text; is defined as at least 18 point regular or 14 point bold. However, when charts are presented as images, the text size often changes. It is therefore always best to aim for a 4.5:1 contrast ratio. To go even further, WCAG success criterion 1.4.6 states that text and images of text should have a contrast ratio of at least 7:1. As a level AAA criterion, this would meet and then exceed legal requirements in the UK.

Never use an image as a background to your data visualisation. This can make its content difficult to see. Data visualisations that use an image as a background are also likely to fail accessibility criteria from WCAG.

Calculate a contrast ratio

To calculate the contrast ratio between two colours to check if they meet these requirements, use our tool below. You will need to find the HEX codes of your colours first. To do so in Microsoft programmes:

  1. Select the graphical element or object of interest
  2. Select the ‘Format’ ribbon
  3. Select the ‘Shape Fill’ dropdown
  4. Select ‘More Fill Colours’
  5. Select ‘Custom’
  6. If your background colour is white, the hex code for white is: #FFFFFF.
  7. Read off the hex code (it starts with a hashtag symbol (#))

Then insert the HEX codes into our tool, and compare the outputted ratio to the WCAG guidelines.

Our colour palettes have been designed to meet best practice guidelines for accessibility, including the WCAG. We encourage you to use these in your data visualisations, but be mindful of any branding your institution may have.

Accessibility & Formatting General Principles

Using colour

Effective use of colour in data visualisation helps the brain quickly identify differences and can aid interpretation. However, using the wrong colours, too many colours, or unnecessary colours, can have the opposite effect.

Think carefully before you introduce additional colours into a chart. Ask yourself:

  • Do you really need the colours?
  • Do they make your key message or messages clearer?
  • The colours you use should be sufficiently unique in tone and contrast. They should also account for users with low vision and colour blindness.

The guidance below expands on how you can achieve this. Colour guidance on axes, chart labels, annotations, and gridlines is included in the Other Formatting Considerations section below.

If you need to use a legend for stacked or clustered bar charts, order the legend to match the categories as they appear in the chart. This does not completely solve the problem, but it can help users work out the series labels without relying only on colour.

can make its content difficult to see. Data visualisations that use an image as a background are also likely to fail accessibility criteria from WCAG.

Consider associations

Colours come with their own symbolic associations. Think about these when choosing your palette. Consider whether your colours are appropriate. If done well, you can exploit these associations to help your users understand your visualisation more quickly.

For example, people tend to link blue with water and green with grass. Using these types of links in data visualisations can help people understand information faster. If you use colours that go against these associations, it might take users longer to understand your chart. For example, it

would take users longer to understand you were talking about grass if you used the colour red to represent it. Colours can also have cultural associations that we react to consciously or unconsciously. These associations vary across countries and groups. Make sure you investigate any possible associations first if you are sharing your data visualisations with international audiences.

f shades of a similar colour are used across categories in a chart, users may assume they are related. If your data has distinct (i.e. discrete or unrelated) categories, then you should use distinct colours.

Keep your colour palettes consistent

If you have multiple data visualisations in a publication, assign the same colour to the same categories in each one. If you change the way you use colours in a series of charts it becomes harder for users to follow the story. It can also cause them to mistake one data series for another, especially if a user is skim reading.

It is therefore always best to aim for a 4.5:1 contrast ratio. To go even further, WCAG success criterion 1.4.6 states that text and images of text should have a contrast ratio of at least 7:1. To calculate the contrast ratio between two colours to check if they meet these requirements, use our tool below. You will need to find the HEX codes of your colours first. To do so in Microsoft programmes:

  1. Select the graphical element or object of interest
  2. Select the ‘Format’ ribbon
  3. Select the ‘Shape Fill’ dropdown
  4. Select ‘More Fill Colours’
  5. Select ‘Custom’
  6. If your background colour is white, the hex code for white is: #FFFFFF.
  7. Read off the hex code (it starts with a hashtag symbol (#))

Then insert the HEX codes into our tool, and compare the outputted ratio to the WCAG guidelines.

Although differences in tone (for example, red, green, and blue) can make your colours distinguishable for many users, this may not be enough for users with colour-blindness. One of the best ways we can account for users with colour-blindness is via the use of contrast, which is typically measured via contrast ratios.

Effective use of contrast also ensures that your visualisations are readable if, for example, it is printed in black and white. It may be helpful to switch your display settings to greyscale to test whether you can identify differences, whether you have colour-blindness or not.

Contrast ratios range between 1:1 (white on white) and 21:1 (black on white). Generally, a moderate level of contrast is the most desirable, but the WCAG include specific thresholds you should aim to pass at minimum.

There are two success criteria in the WCAG that refer to contrast ratios: 1.4.11.

The visual presentation of parts of graphics required to understand the content have a contrast ratio of at least 3 to 1 against adjacent colours except when a particular presentation is essential. This means that all chart elements (such as categories in a bar chart) must have at least a 3:1 contrast ratio with adjacent colours, unless the presentation is essential for communicating your key message. 1.4.3. Contrast (minimum)

The visual presentation of text and images of text has a contrast ratio of at least 4.5:1, except for large scale text which needs to have a contrast ratio of at least 3:1. This means you should make sure that all chart labels and annotations have at least a 4.5: contrast ratio with the background colour.

Large scale text; is defined as at least 18 point regular or 14 point bold. However, when charts are presented as images, the text size often changes. It is therefore always best to aim for a 4.5:1 contrast ratio. To go even further, WCAG success criterion 1.4.6 states that text and images of text should have a contrast ratio of at least 7:1. As a level AAA criterion, this would meet and then exceed legal requirements in the UK.

Never use an image as a background to your data visualisation. This can make its content difficult to see. Data visualisations that use an image as a background are also likely to fail accessibility criteria from WCAG.

Calculate a contrast ratio

To calculate the contrast ratio between two colours to check if they meet these requirements, use our tool below. You will need to find the HEX codes of your colours first. To do so in Microsoft programmes:

  1. Select the graphical element or object of interest
  2. Select the ‘Format’ ribbon
  3. Select the ‘Shape Fill’ dropdown
  4. Select ‘More Fill Colours’
  5. Select ‘Custom’
  6. If your background colour is white, the hex code for white is: #FFFFFF.
  7. Read off the hex code (it starts with a hashtag symbol (#))

Then insert the HEX codes into our tool, and compare the outputted ratio to the WCAG guidelines.

Our colour palettes have been designed to meet best practice guidelines for accessibility, including the WCAG. We encourage you to use these in your data visualisations, but be mindful of any branding your institution may have.

Accessibility & Formatting General Principles

Using colour

Effective use of colour in data visualisation helps the brain quickly identify differences and can aid interpretation. However, using the wrong colours, too many colours, or unnecessary colours, can have the opposite effect.

Think carefully before you introduce additional colours into a chart. Ask yourself:

  • Do you really need the colours?
  • Do they make your key message or messages clearer?
  • The colours you use should be sufficiently unique in tone and contrast. They should also account for users with low vision and colour blindness.

The guidance below expands on how you can achieve this. Colour guidance on axes, chart labels, annotations, and gridlines is included in the Other Formatting Considerations section below.

Colour should be used to enhance your data visualisation. You should use different colours when they help to highlight differences in the data, but they should ideally not be the only way you convey those differences.

The WCAG state that: 1.4.1. Use of colour

Colour is not used as the only visual means of conveying information. This means that you should help users understand charts without relying only on colour. To do this, you should avoid using legends in line charts and pie charts. Instead, label the categories and lines in your chart.

If you need to use a legend for stacked or clustered bar charts, order the legend to match the categories as they appear in the chart. This does not completely solve the problem, but it can help users work out the series labels without relying only on colour.

Use the right number of colours

Some data visualisations, such as a simple bar chart with one independent and one dependent variable, only need one colour across categories. The user is much more likely to compare the bars when they look alike than when they look different. Sometimes it is helpful to highlight a specific category to bring it into focus. In these cases, use one colour for this category (for example, dark blue), while keeping the others the same (for example, grey).

Other types of data visualisation, such as a clustered bar chart, or a line graph showing multiple time series, are likely to benefit from having multiple colours. However, you should avoid using more than five colours in the same chart. Having more than five colours makes it harder for users to distinguish between categories.

When people look at a chart with lots of colours, they try to work out what those different colours mean. If your colours suggest meanings that are not there the user will waste time and effort trying to understand them. This creates cognitive burden on the user and makes it harder for them to engage with your analysis.

can make its content difficult to see. Data visualisations that use an image as a background are also likely to fail accessibility criteria from WCAG.

Consider associations

Colours come with their own symbolic associations. Think about these when choosing your palette. Consider whether your colours are appropriate. If done well, you can exploit these associations to help your users understand your visualisation more quickly.

For example, people tend to link blue with water and green with grass. Using these types of links in data visualisations can help people understand information faster. If you use colours that go against these associations, it might take users longer to understand your chart. For example, it

would take users longer to understand you were talking about grass if you used the colour red to represent it. Colours can also have cultural associations that we react to consciously or unconsciously. These associations vary across countries and groups. Make sure you investigate any possible associations first if you are sharing your data visualisations with international audiences.

f shades of a similar colour are used across categories in a chart, users may assume they are related. If your data has distinct (i.e. discrete or unrelated) categories, then you should use distinct colours.

Keep your colour palettes consistent

If you have multiple data visualisations in a publication, assign the same colour to the same categories in each one. If you change the way you use colours in a series of charts it becomes harder for users to follow the story. It can also cause them to mistake one data series for another, especially if a user is skim reading.

Consider contrast ratios

Although differences in tone (for example, red, green, and blue) can make your colours distinguishable for many users, this may not be enough for users with colour-blindness. One of the best ways we can account for users with colour-blindness is via the use of contrast, which is typically measured via contrast ratios.

Effective use of contrast also ensures that your visualisations are readable if, for example, it is printed in black and white. It may be helpful to switch your display settings to greyscale to test whether you can identify differences, whether you have colour-blindness or not.

Contrast ratios range between 1:1 (white on white) and 21:1 (black on white). Generally, a moderate level of contrast is the most desirable, but the WCAG include specific thresholds you should aim to pass at minimum.

There are two success criteria in the WCAG that refer to contrast ratios: 1.4.11.

The visual presentation of parts of graphics required to understand the content have a contrast ratio of at least 3 to 1 against adjacent colours except when a particular presentation is essential. This means that all chart elements (such as categories in a bar chart) must have at least a 3:1 contrast ratio with adjacent colours, unless the presentation is essential for communicating your key message. 1.4.3. Contrast (minimum)

The visual presentation of text and images of text has a contrast ratio of at least 4.5:1, except for large scale text which needs to have a contrast ratio of at least 3:1. This means you should make sure that all chart labels and annotations have at least a 4.5: contrast ratio with the background colour.

Large scale text; is defined as at least 18 point regular or 14 point bold. However, when charts are presented as images, the text size often changes. It is therefore always best to aim for a 4.5:1 contrast ratio. To go even further, WCAG success criterion 1.4.6 states that text and images of text should have a contrast ratio of at least 7:1. As a level AAA criterion, this would meet and then exceed legal requirements in the UK.

Never use an image as a background to your data visualisation. This can make its content difficult to see. Data visualisations that use an image as a background are also likely to fail accessibility criteria from WCAG.

Calculate a contrast ratio

To calculate the contrast ratio between two colours to check if they meet these requirements, use our tool below. You will need to find the HEX codes of your colours first. To do so in Microsoft programmes:

  1. Select the graphical element or object of interest
  2. Select the ‘Format’ ribbon
  3. Select the ‘Shape Fill’ dropdown
  4. Select ‘More Fill Colours’
  5. Select ‘Custom’
  6. If your background colour is white, the hex code for white is: #FFFFFF.
  7. Read off the hex code (it starts with a hashtag symbol (#))

Then insert the HEX codes into our tool, and compare the outputted ratio to the WCAG guidelines.

Our colour palettes have been designed to meet best practice guidelines for accessibility, including the WCAG. We encourage you to use these in your data visualisations, but be mindful of any branding your institution may have.

Consider associations

Colours come with their own symbolic associations. Think about these when choosing your palette. Consider whether your colours are appropriate. If done well, you can exploit these associations to help your users understand your visualisation more quickly.

For example, people tend to link blue with water and green with grass. Using these types of links in data visualisations can help people understand information faster. If you use colours that go against these associations, it might take users longer to understand your chart. For example, it

would take users longer to understand you were talking about grass if you used the colour red to represent it. Colours can also have cultural associations that we react to consciously or unconsciously. These associations vary across countries and groups. Make sure you investigate any possible associations first if you are sharing your data visualisations with international audiences.

If you have multiple data visualisations in a publication, assign the same colour to the same categories in each one. It can also cause them to mistake one data series for another, especially if a user is skim reading.

  1. Select the graphical element or object of interest
  2. Select the ‘Format’ ribbon
  3. Select the ‘Shape Fill’ dropdown
  4. Select ‘More Fill Colours’
  5. Select ‘Custom’
  6. If your background colour is white, the hex code for white is: #FFFFFF.
  7. Read off the hex code (it starts with a hashtag symbol (#))

Then insert the HEX codes into our tool, and compare the outputted ratio to the WCAG guidelines.
